title: Morning MoneyBeat Europe: Chinese Turmoil Keeps Global Investors Cautious
text:
Please feel free to send this email to friends and colleagues and include this link so they can sign up to receive it for free too http://on.wsj.com/MoneyBeatEuropeSignup 
Follow us on Twitter @WSJMoneyBeat. 
The latest turmoil in Chinese markets helped keep global investors in cautious mode Tuesday, with most Asian markets falling and shares in Europe struggling to make headway. 
The Shanghai Composite Index tumbled by more than 6%. The move came despite a massive cash injection into the financial system by the country’s central bank, which signaled Beijing’s growing concerns about capital outflows following the recent weakening of its currency. 
In Europe, the Stoxx Europe 600 index was 0.2% lower in early trade, as the momentum from Monday’s gains in the U.S. faded. 
European shares were hit hard last week by worries that China’s devaluation is a further sign its economy is slowing, and have struggled to make up lost ground even as the yuan has steadied. 
Fears of waning demand from the world’s second-largest economy have also kept commodity prices under pressure 
Read our full take on the markets Tuesday here. 
-- Tommy Stubbington 
Market Snapshot: FTSE 100 down 0.25%, CAC 40 down 0.24% and DAX down 0.11%. Nikkei finished Tuesday down 0.32%. Brent crude down 0.53% at $48.48. Gold down 0.04% at $1117.90. EUR/USD at $1.1089. Ten-year Treasury yield lower at 2.14%, Bund yield lower at 0.61%, Gilt yield lower at 1.81%. 
What You May Have Missed on MoneyBeat 
This Is a Real Number: Second-Quarter Earnings Down 16%: One word describes the bottom line on the bottom line for second-quarter earnings season, and the top line, and the middle lines for that matter: down. 
After China Tailspin, Buy German Stocks — Barings : Beijing’s abrupt shift in its exchange rate setting policy sent shockwaves through global markets last week. Among those hardest hit was Germany where the outlook for big exporters to China looked less than rosy. 
Greek Bank Bondholders Face Bail-Ins : Greek bank debtholders look set to wave goodbye to a big chunk of money, and bond prices are feeling the effects, falling sharply Monday after a statement from the Eurogroup that confirmed investors will be on the hook for recapitalizing ailing banks. 
Dutch Investors Get Tough on Fee Disclosure : Investors in the Netherlands are leading the push for transparency on private equity fees – with some of the major pension plans increasing their requests for information disclosure. 
KBW’s Only Buy Rating Among the Big Banks: J.P. Morgan : KBW Analysts just upgraded to J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.’s stock to an “outperform.” The main reason: a discounted valuation compared to its peers. 
Yuan Devaluation’s More About the Fed Than China — Goldman Sachs : China’s central bank’s decision to devalue its tightly controlled currency last week caused the biggest one-day loss for the currency in two decades. But China’s shock move is more about the dollar and U.S. monetary policy than about the country’s domestic economic challenges, according to Goldman Sachs. 
The Dow Has Set a New Record… for Futility : Few need reminding that U.S. stocks have spent this year trading sideways, directionless. But the length of time that U.S. equities have spent moving in such a narrow range is becoming unprecedented. 
Tesla Is ‘Uniquely Positioned to Dominate’ Auto Business : Tesla shares have had a stellar run over the past two-and-a-half years. If a Morgan Stanley note out Monday is anything to go by, the rally is far from over. 
From The Wall Street Journal 
U.S. Lacks Ammo for Next Economic Crisis: As the U.S. economic expansion ages and clouds gather overseas, policy makers worry about recession. Their concern isn’t that a downturn is imminent but whether they will have firepower to fight back when one does arrive. 
China Shares Tumble Despite Cash Injection: China led Asian markets lower Tuesday, shrugging off signals of recovery in its housing market and the central bank’s fresh steps to offset outflows in the wake of a weaker currency. 
The Hot Thing for Wall Street Banks: Capital-Relief Trades: Faced with new global regulations requiring them to strengthen their capital, big lenders in the U.S. and Europe have turned to a trading tactic that flatters their positions without actually raising extra funds. 
Merkel Allies Try to Contain Rebellion on Greek Vote: Allies of German Chancellor Angela Merkel intensified their efforts to prevent a rebellion in their ranks two days before a crucial vote in Parliament on a new, €86 billion ($95 billion) bailout package for Greece. 
PBOC Injection Shows China Worries About Outflows: China’s central bank injected the largest amount of cash into the financial system on a single day in almost 19 months Tuesday, signaling Beijing’s growing concerns about capital outflows following the recent weakening of its currency.
